annotation.TEXT: Beyond that, there's some solid changes that make this hack worth playing. Despite boss weaknesses not being fully implemented yet, all of the weapons are extremely good. They each have their own unique uses, and they're insanely fun to play around with in each stage (especially Master Helper).

As a final note though, both of the orbs are weak to Beat. I have no idea if they can be hurt by the Power Adapter, but I wouldn't recommend using it on these things either way, considering how much maneuverability they have.

The blue orb is weak to Silver Wing, Lost Botany, Devil Torch, and Psycho Impact. Red is weak to everything else. You really need to keep this weakness set in mind during this fight, mostly considering the orbs will heal themselves if you use the wrong weapon on them.

For now though, I think I already have my next playthrough planned out. I have 3 particular games I wanted to try out next, one of which is a Castlevania fan-game that I'm not even sure if I'll be able to record properly (mostly due to its weird window-size settings).

So then, that's Rockman 6 Skype, or at least what's done of it so far. Incidentally, this part of the credits is also another tip-off that this game is incomplete...mostly due to some of the Robot Masters not appearing in their correct rooms. Thankfully, this doesn't have the potential to soft-lock the game.

In terms of level design, some of the stages are a bit iffy (Blizzard and Wind Man's stages specifically), but there's a few that are kind of interesting as well. Flame and Centaur are probably my favorite stages in this hack, if partly for the music.

Although, if anyone actually does want to take a guess as to what these games I've mentioned are, feel free to do so. I'll point it out if someone manages to guess them correctly based on my descriptions here. Either way, I'll probably start with the Mega Man games first (due to the aforementioned window issues with the previously mentioned game).

Wily 3 is a bit of an oddity. In the original, it was basically just a dull path filled with water, spikes, and fans that lead up to the boss rematches. Here on the other hand, it's an actual stage...albeit, one with a rather bizarre layout.

As noted in the previous video, the Wily fortress is somewhat unchanged as well, though to a lesser extent than the Mr. X stages. Wily 1 and 3 are the only modified levels so far, and are a fair bit longer in comparison to some of the other stages.

Overall though, this hack obviously had a lot of time and effort put into it. With the exception of the main path in Mr. X 1, it's still playable even in its unfinished state. With that being said, I can't wait to see what else will be in here once this is all completed. The orbs at the end of Wily 3 alone are a clear indication of what the creator is capable of, and I'd love to see what other changes they could make to the other fortress bosses.

Wily 1 is actually a combination of several layouts from other Wily fortresses. I'm not sure how I feel about this concept, but I do like the fact that these areas are recognizable more-so for the actual layouts themselves, rather than just copy-pasting graphics from the original games.

Even for being incomplete at the moment, this hack really shows a lot of promise, and a potential bright future for Mega Man 6 in terms of more in-depth hacks. Really, it's about time someone focused on this game while actually making extensive changes, as opposed to just switching up the layout/graphics.

The other two are Mega Man fan-games games, both of which are a part of the same "series," and both of which are essentially boss rush games. I'm also willing to bet not a lot of people watching this have even played or heard of these, so it should be an interesting experience one I get around to them.

I'm not sure how to properly describe this place, but I suppose "small rooms with clusters of enemies" is accurate enough. That's what most of this stage is about (along with the boss rematches). There is however, one new thing we'll be seeing at the end...

Out of nowhere, we get to fight a completely original boss. These two orbs share a single health bar (similar to the Giant Suzies from Rockman 4 MI), and both throw out different elemental attacks. They also can't be hurt by the buster. Instead, they have specific weaknesses to certain weapons.

Admittedly, there are a few issues here and there with this one. The biggest comes from the bosses, especially given the sharp 180 when comparing the modified AI on a few of them (Flame Man being easier than he was in the original, while Wind Man is the most annoying boss in the game).

Once you finish the boss rematches, the stage isn't quite done yet. Out of all the new content in this hack, it seems the most drastic modifications (even more-so than Knight Man's) were saved for the end of this stage.
I'm just going to hope that Plant Man isn't capable of doing that in the final version. In any case, I'm sure the exploit in his boss room will be fixed, along with him actually having a weakness.

Speaking of music, this hack has a rather solid soundtrack as well. To be honest, I wasn't able to recognize a good portion of the custom tracks (except for the title screen's coming from Romacing Saga 3's boss theme, and Plant Man's coming from Shatterhand's Area B theme). Even then however, a lot of the renditions here are extremely well done.
